title.narrative: OUTPUT 028: M&E

description.narrative: The Government of Ghana is supported to generate and use equity-focused data, evaluations, and analytical studies to plan, monitor, and evaluate programmes that advance children's rights at national and decentralized levels., which contributes to Building Capacity For Evaluation, Child Poverty / Public Finance For Children, Children In Urban Settings / Local Governance, Cross-Sectoral Communication For Development, Cross-Sectoral Monitoring, Data And Situation Analyses, Evaluation And Research, Operations Support To Programme Delivery, Social Exclusion â€“ Data And Evidence. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 8: Policy analysis and advocacy, M&E, and Communications: Policy analysis and advocacy, M&E, and external Communications are based on evidence, linked to functional M&E systems, and are used to reduce child poverty and encourage equitable development.

sector.narrative: Building evaluation capacity in UNICEF and the UN system
Child marriage - surveys (e.g. KAP, VACS), data analysis/research/evaluation evidence generation, synthesis, and use
Child poverty analysis towards policy change (Profiling, mapping and identifying drivers of multi-dimensional and monetary poverty of children, modelling and simulation of policy options)
Child poverty measurement: support to routine national measurement of monetary and multidimensional child poverty
Country programme process (including UNDAF planning and CCA)
Evaluation innovation learning, uptake and partnerships for evaluation
Innovation, multi-media content production and dissemination
PF4C - domestic revenue mobilization and access to finance for key social services
Social and behaviour change communication on violence, exploitation and abuse
Stimulating demand for and capacity to use data

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: The Government of Ghana is supported to generate and use equity-focused data, evaluations, and analytical studies to plan, monitor, and evaluate programmes that advance children's rights at national and decentralized levels.

description.narrative: UNICEF Ghana in collaboration with its partners supported government institutions with a national statistical systems assessment, systems strengthening, capacity-building and advocacy for the improvement of data accessibility across key sectors. UNICEF successfully rolled out the Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey. | Status:Met | As-of Date:21/12/2017

title.narrative: Percentage of key national surveys that are led by MDAs and provide evidence-based analysis on the situation of children and women.

actual.value: 2017:100%. Ghana MICS6 successfully rolled out and training of data collectors, supervisors and monitors was finalized in October 2017. The Ghana Statistical Services (GSS) is leading the survey with technical and financial support from UNICEF. Data collection is currently underway and is expected to be

title.narrative: Number of key MDAs in the five UNICEF priority sectors that have robust decentralised M&E systems providing equity-focused data for evidence-based decision making.

actual.value: 2017:4. (EMIS, DHIMS, LEAP and BASIS) decentralized M&E systems. The Child Protection Management Information System (CPMIS) was not finalized this year since plans and preparations are still ongoing with government partners.

title.narrative: Existence of high-quality research on social norms that govern 6 key behaviours

actual.value: 2017:A research on Social Norms and Behaviors Related to Child Survival in Ghana was conducted in 2017. The overall objective of the research was to provide a better understanding of the ways in which social norms, in select districts in Ghana, influence the behaviors related to child survival.
